intro: Cestrum albopunctatum, commonly known as the white-spotted cestrum, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It is a member of the Solanaceae family, which includes nightshade plants, and is characterized by its showy, fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 6 meters, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow with a distinctive white or pale green spots, and they bloom in clusters during the summer months. The plant is also known for its mildly toxic berries, which contain alkaloids and should be handled with care.
